In Michigan, a 14-year-old boy named James Persyn III was babysitting his siblings when a woman knocked on the door, claiming she had been kidnapped. The boy locked doors, grabbed a hunting knife, and called 911 as the woman's attackers approached.

A homeowner in Miami shot and killed a 17-year-old burglary suspect who had broken into her home. The victim's family expressed outrage over the killing, questioning whether justice was served.

In Texas, an undocumented immigrant named Margarito Quintero Rosales was deported twice before killing a firefighter and his two young children in a car accident. A judge later sentenced him to a reduced sentence.

RELIABLE NEWS SUMMARY
---------------------
A woman, Ms. Rojas, claimed to have been abducted and murdered, but her story changed, leading police to investigate. They found she had delivered a premature baby at a hospital and left it on a bus with relatives nearby. A family's estate was established for four children who were homeless, with donations going towards their education and medical expenses.

A mother, Susana Ramos, lives in a cramped apartment with her three daughters and works multiple jobs to support them. She clips coupons to save money and volunteers at a local early head start program. A woman, Crystal Gonzalez, is still grieving the loss of her 16-year-old daughter who was accidentally shot by a friend.

Climate change is a pressing global issue, with devastating consequences such as melting glaciers, forest fires, and extreme weather events. Despite the growing evidence, many politicians and media outlets have failed to address the issue seriously.

The US has taken a backseat in international climate talks, with Japan playing a pivotal role. The Kyoto treaty, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, is at risk of being derailed due to opposition from industries and some politicians.

The Paris Agreement, signed last year, sets goals for global climate action, including limiting temperature increases to well below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit (2 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial norms. However, the agreement's implementation has been slow, with many countries failing to meet their commitments.

Climate change is also having a significant impact on coastal communities and oceans, with sea-level rise and increased storm intensity becoming more frequent. The US has seen devastating effects, including Superstorm Sandy, which caused over $70 billion in economic damage.

The Trump administration's environmental nominees have been questioned about climate change science, with some denying its validity. Despite this, the administration has issued a report confirming that human activities are causing the planet to warm.

International talks on climate change have resulted in vague commitments and promises, rather than concrete goals or action plans. Experts have expressed disappointment with the lack of progress, citing the need for significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions to avoid catastrophic climate change.

Overall, the facts suggest that climate change is a pressing global issue that requires immediate attention and action from governments, industries, and individuals around the world.

RELIABLE NEWS SUMMARY
---------------------
Climate change is a pressing global issue, with devastating consequences such as melting glaciers, forest fires, and extreme weather events. Despite the growing evidence, many politicians and media outlets have failed to address the issue seriously.

The US has taken a backseat in international climate talks, with Japan playing a pivotal role. The Kyoto treaty, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, is at risk of being derailed due to opposition from industries and some politicians.

The Paris Agreement, signed last year, sets goals for global climate action, including limiting temperature increases to well below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit (2 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial norms. However, the agreement's implementation has been slow, with many countries failing to meet their commitments.

Climate change is also having a significant impact on coastal communities and oceans, with sea-level rise and increased storm intensity becoming more frequent. The US has seen devastating effects, including Superstorm Sandy, which caused over $70 billion in economic damage.

The Trump administration's environmental nominees have been questioned about climate change science, with some denying its validity. Despite this, the administration has issued a report confirming that human activities are causing the planet to warm.

International talks on climate change have resulted in vague commitments and promises, rather than concrete goals or action plans. Experts have expressed disappointment with the lack of progress, citing the need for significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions to avoid catastrophic climate change.

Overall, the facts suggest that climate change is a pressing global issue that requires immediate attention

Yoga originated in ancient India, linked to Hinduism and meditation practices. The word "yoga" first appears in the Rig Veda, a sacred text from around 1500 BCE. Islamic clerics have issued fatwas prohibiting yoga for Muslims since 2004.

Rudraksha, a precious stone symbolizing Lord Shiva, is believed to have healing properties. It's thought to help heal the human body medically and protect against negative energy. Rudraksha trees are found in India, Nepal, and Southeast Asia.

Tibetan medicine has been recognized by UNESCO, but its commercial development raises concerns about watering down traditional formulas and over-harvesting medicinal ingredients. The discipline is practiced in China, India, and neighboring countries.

In India, pilgrims gather at the Sangam, a confluence of three holy rivers, to take an immersion bath believed to bring eternal salvation. The notion of pilgrimage is powerful in predominantly Hindu India.

Indian classical dance forms have been reconstructed and altered over time. Odissi, one of these forms, originated in the state of Orissa on India's east coast. American Indian teachings are used as a compass by some women in tech, including Suzanne Randall, managing director at Accenture.

These articles highlight various aspects of Indian culture, spirituality, and traditions, showcasing the country's rich heritage and diverse practices.

FAKE NEWS SUMMARY
-----------------
The concept of chakras, or energy centers in the body, is rooted in Eastern metaphysical theories and Ayurvedic Indian medicine. These "places" are correlated with physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual well-being.

Research has shown that human thoughts, emotions, and intentions can affect and alter our physical material world, including biology. The observer creates reality, and the universe begins to look more like a great thought than a machine.

Reiki healing is possible because everything is energy, and all things are connected through a subtle, underlying energy matrix. Energy healing treats a person holistically, looking at the causes of conditions rather than just symptoms.

The concept of avatars, such as Manu, who are believed to have played a significant role in shaping human culture, exists in various traditions. The idea of a universal energy code is also present, with some researchers exploring its connection to chakras and spiritual practices.

Crystals can interact with the body's natural subtle energies, holding vibrations that correspond to specific colors and energies. This concept is used in crystal healing, which aims to balance and align the body's energy centers.

The idea of a new chakra, known as the Soulight Chakra, has been proposed by some researchers, linking it to the inner earth sun and the unification of dimensions. The concept of light codes and templates is also present, with some researchers exploring their connection to spiritual practices and personal growth.

Overall, these concepts are rooted in Eastern metaphysical theories

RELIABLE NEWS SUMMARY

New York is facing a financial crisis marked by anemic tax collections and the prolonged sluggishness on Wall Street. Governor George E. Pataki proposed a budget plan in January that cut state aid to schools and sharply curbed healthcare spending, but was vetoed by the legislature. The legislature then overrode Pataki's vetoes, reviving a budget that increases state taxes to restore billions of dollars in spending on schools, hospitals, nursing homes, and localities.

Pataki is considering running for re-election or possibly presidential candidacy, despite his advisors saying he has not told anyone he will run. The governor's intentions are preoccupying Albany, where lobbyists with ties to the administration are fretting about a future without Pataki.

A budget deal was reached between Governor Andrew Cuomo and legislative leaders, which includes cuts to the court system, including hundreds of layoffs. The state is expected to rely on unpalatable alternatives, such as deep spending cuts and tax increases, to address its fiscal predicament.

New York's budget gap is expected to grow, with some options being considered, including extending a surcharge on taxable earnings or borrowing against projected revenues from casinos planned for the Catskills. The state faced an even larger budget gap two years ago but was able to close it by borrowing more than $4 billion against future tobacco revenues.

Title: high concepts fall flat on the palate
Content: luxee 6 clinton street (east houston street); (212) 375-1796. it’s easy to like luxee, the dessert bar that opened last month on the lower east side. it feels like a simple neighborhood cafe, but it’s actually a satellite of l’école vantan, a fashion and culinary school in tokyo. all the meticulously composed desserts are organic, though whether they’re good for you, as luxee claims, is a discussion for you and your nutritionist. photo too bad some of these high concepts fall flat on the palate. the menu is short: five desserts, two salads and several kinds of cookies, including the addictive rosemary sablés ($7 for a box of 11). but the vegan green forest parfait ($12), a chocolate mousse made with whipped avocado, could have used some of the sin of dairy, while the normandy cheesecake ($12), made with camembert, could have used less. the chef’s special caramel apple ($14), on the other hand, is a masterpiece, three manifestations of caramel (in a milk chocolate mousse, as a brittle and as a sauce), matched by four stages of apple (frozen in a sorbet with basil, as a gelée, in a semifreddo and as a neat row of raw slices), all arrayed beneath a sugar dome as thin as a soap bubble. it’s an impressive sight. the interplay of flavors is kaleidoscopic, all you imagine caramel and apples could be. what a shame that it feels grandly out of place, a course in search of a meal.

emerging intact from the deep freeze of the bush years, syria has more power to dictate the terms of its new relationship with washington. at the same time, some figures in the syrian leadership are nevertheless, there may be real opportunities for diplomatic progress, in part because some of the issues that divided syria and the united states in recent years appear to have subsided. last year’s doha accord resolved the political crisis, at least for now, in lebanon , where the united states long accused syria of playing a destabilizing role. syria and saudi arabia are also said to have reached an agreement not to interfere in the lebanese parliamentary elections in june, and syria and lebanon have established formal diplomatic ties. in iraq , syria’s goals are now similar to those Content: (photo: reuters/brian c. frank) u.s. republican presidential candidate ted cruz speaks at a 2nd amendment coalition announcement at crossroads shooting sports in johnston, iowa, december 4, 2015. with ted cruz surging in iowa and some national polls, gop frontrunner donald trump took a jab at the texas senator's faith, saying, "not a lot of evangelicals come out of cuba." cruz's father, rafael, 76, was born in cuba and is a popular evangelical pastor and christian speaker. cruz was born in alberta, canada while his parents worked in the oil business. his mother is from delaware. trump told iowans friday, "i am an evangelical. i'm a christian. i'm a presbyterian." cruz is now in a statistical tie with trump in iowa according to a new poll. cruz leads trump 28 to 26 percent in a fox news iowa poll released monday. trump noted that he has a positive view of cruz but told the crowd, "i do like ted cruz, but not a lot of evangelicals come out of cuba." cruz's father fled cuba in the late 1950s and says he became a born again christian in the 1970s while attending bible study. in late october, trump questioned fellow candidate ben carson's christian faith when carson was tied with him in iowa polls, suggesting that his presbyterian faith is more mainstream than carson's seventh-day adventist denomination. presbyterian is "down the middle of the road folks, in all fairness. i mean, seventh-day adventist, i don't know about. i just don't know about," he said. cruz has been reluctant to criticize trump on the campaign trail, but has been accused by trump of privately attacking him behind closed doors. cruz "should not make statements behind closed doors to his bosses, he should bring them out into the open — more fun that way!" tweeted trump friday. "looks like @tedcruz is getting ready to attack. i am leading by so much he must. i hope so, he will fall like all others. will be easy!" noted trump on twitter. according to a monmouth university poll released monday, the billionaire gop frontrunner widened his national lead over the field. the poll found that outside of cruz and trump supporters, gop voters do not feel that trump has the right temperament to be president. expand | collapse reuters / mary schwalm u.s. republican presidential candidate donald trump waves as he leaves the stage after speaking at the meeting of the new england police benevolent association in portsmouth, new hampshire. december 10, 2015. "it has become abundantly clear that trump is giving his supporters exactly what they want, even if what he says causes the gop leadership and many republican voters to cringe"

FAKE NEWS SUMMARY
-----------------
Ted Cruz, a US Senator from Texas, has been in the news for various reasons. He recently spoke at the Texas GOP convention, where he endorsed his son Ted Cruz for Senate and criticized Carly Fiorina's presidential campaign. Rafael Cruz, Ted's father, also spoke at the event, criticizing Fiorina and stating that his son would "come back guns blazing" despite past mistakes.

Ted Cruz has also been vocal about getting 54 million evangelicals to vote in elections, believing that Christians should desire a president who prays, seeks Christ, and loves God. He has also pledged to secure the US border with land mines if elected president.

However, his record on charitable donations has raised questions about his commitment to Christian values. According to tax returns, Cruz gave less than 1% of his income to charity between 2006 and 2010.

Ted Cruz has also made headlines for his comments on "New York values," which he described as socially liberal or pro-abortion. He has been criticized for disparaging New Yorkers and has faced backlash from the public.

In a debate, Donald Trump acknowledged that he was bringing up Ted Cruz's Canadian birthplace to boost his own polls, but Cruz deftly swatted away the taunts. Despite this, Cruz remains committed to his presidential campaign and believes he will win fair and square.

* Ted Cruz's high evangelical turnout in the Iowa caucus is attributed to his ability to "awaken" and "energize" Christian conservative voters.
* Jeb Bush, a Catholic, emphasizes the importance of his faith guiding him as a public leader and has championed faith-based social services.
* 38 members of Congress urge Secretary of State John Kerry to use every legal means to rescue Meriam Ibrahim, a Christian mother sentenced to death in Sudan for refusing to renounce her faith.
* Latino evangelicals in Florida are considered a swing voter due to their diverse views on issues like immigration and abortion.
* White evangelical Christians face a reckoning after Donald Trump's win, with some questioning the group's loyalty to him despite his divisive policies.
* Jeb Bush touts his core Christian beliefs at various forums, including his support for defunding Planned Parenthood as governor of Florida.
* An evangelical pastor freed in Obama's Iran prisoner swap had a vision that Donald Trump would be president and wants the US to declare itself a "Christian country".
* A Massachusetts state court rules that a Catholic school cannot deny employment over gay marriage, citing state discrimination laws.

These points highlight key themes and facts from various articles.

Article 6 - what reality tv teaches us about russia’s influence campaign
over the past few days, i reached out to several reality show producers, asking them to compare the russian digital influence campaign and the world of unscripted tv. the more they told me about reality shows, the more the metaphor seemed to explain russia’s trolling campaign — how it worked, what it aimed to do and why campaigns like it will be so difficult to fight. the only thing that matters is drama. one of the more surprising findings about the russian influence campaign is its political incoherence. the documents released so far suggest that, as in the houston protest, the trolls didn’t seem to care very much about pushing one political side over another. they were happy to push all sides — to get people to argue for and against the islamic library — which suggests their ultimate goal was to sow drama. why? reality tv offers a guide: because drama is easy to produce, and because drama sells. on a show where the action stems from the interplay of people living in close quarters — like “the bachelor” — there are often producers on set who subtly, and sometimes less than subtly, prod the contestants into acting in certain ways. how often this happens, and to what degree, varies greatly from show to show and is matter of great secrecy and controversy within the industry. but pretty much everyone in the world of reality tv acknowledges that it happens to some degree on most shows, and that there are certain basic ways to manufacture drama. sarah gertrude shapiro

Title: losing touch with reality
Content: ''the littlest groom,'' fox's new show in which the audience is invited to gawk as a 4-foot-5 man searches for a bride, may mark an exploitative new low in television programming. it may also be the tip-off that reality television has ''jumped the shark,'' tv-aficionado lingo for the point at which programming makes a final leap into witlessness and heads irredeemably into reruns. it is hard to become too nostalgic for the golden days of reality tv, since the genre has always been a slightly sour cocktail of exploitation, voyeurism and humiliation. but looking back, it now seems as if there was a kind of innocence to the first ''survivor'' group to do darwinian battle on a deserted south china sea island, or the first ''fear factor'' contestants to munch live bugs on national television. reality television, however, demands novelty. so the networks, eyes fixed firmly on the nielsen ratings, became eager carny barkers, beckoning audiences to increasingly lurid variations on the theme. the deserted island became ''temptation island,'' where attractive singles tried to break up ''committed couples.'' on ''fear factor,'' bug eating gave way, in a recent episode, to men diving into dumpsters and pulling out pig uteruses and cow stomachs for their girlfriends to eat. american networks are not alone in this race to the bottom. last year, british television broadcast ''celebrity detox camp,'' which featured famous people getting enemas. ''jumping the shark,'' as the web site www.jumptheshark.com explains, refers to a ''happy days'' episode in which fonzie was on water skis and tried to jump over a shark, a stunt widely viewed as the beginning of the end for the series. reality tv is still well represented in the nielsens, but given its current state, it's hard to imagine that will last for long. of course, just as reality television succeeded the craze inspired by ''who wants to be a millionaire,'' there is undoubtedly a new genre waiting in the wings. we're sure whatever it is will make for compelling viewing.

Standard & Poor's (S&P) has downgraded Portugal and Greece again, citing concerns about the countries' ability to pay their debts. S&P warned that investors may be forced to dump short-dated Portuguese debt to protect themselves from default, making it harder for Lisbon to raise money by issuing short-dated bills.

Content: greek prosecutor calls papandreou, papaconstantinou on 2009-revised deficit (before it's news) a bombshell with a weight of at least one mega-tone was dropped in the picturesque city of athens on friday afternoon. thus while greek government officials have been dealing with the troika on the left and the private greek bond holders on the right. economic prosecutor grigoris peponis requested in a letter to prosecutor of supreme court that former prime minister george papandreou, former finance minister george papaconstantinou and other members of the economic team of the previous government would be checked on ‘any possible criminal liabilities” concerning the budget deficit of 2009 that was upwards revised by the greek statistics authority (elstat). peponis requested that the file would be submitted to the greek parliament. ﻿﻿﻿the economic prosecutor mentions the names of 18 people who have testified on the case and underlines that ”in the majority of testimonies, it has been explicitly referred to artificial swelling and arbitrary determination of the public deficit in 2009 at one hand, and possible responsibilities of the then prime minister, members of the then government and the then ministers of finance.” the move caused concerns at the supreme court because the president of the elstat had not be invited to testify by the prosecutor. the move caused surprise in the coalition government partner pasok because the last think papandreou-supporters would need now is an investigation against their party leader – even if he is thinking of resigning form the party leadership. the move caused no reaction in the public opinion becasue no greek is willing to believe that any greek politician would ever testify for anything or be held responsible. for further reading on revised budget deficit 2oo9 , new scandal with elstat? read more at keep talking greece source:

The company is also developing hybrid vehicles, such as the Avalon XLE Premium I, which combines a 2.5-liter engine with two electric motor-generators.

In Japan, the government is pushing for subsidies and tax breaks to bring the cost of fuel-cell cars down to around $20,000 by 2025. The country aims to create 100 hydrogen fuel stations by the end of March 2016.

Overall, Toyota's shift towards mass-producing long-range EVs marks a significant change in its strategy, as the company seeks to adapt to changing market demands and regulatory requirements.

Colombia's government and Marxist rebels signed a revised peace accord, aiming to end 52 years of conflict. The agreement was rejected in a referendum last month but is expected to be approved by Congress. A bilateral ceasefire has been broken for the first time since its implementation, with two rebels killed in combat.

The accord includes provisions to disarm rebels, who have been extorting people and carrying weapons. Rebels were ordered to stop offensive military activities, including sabotage, as part of a two-month cease-fire announced earlier. The government and rebels are set to sign the final agreement on Thursday.

A majority of Colombians support peace talks with Marxist rebels, but doubt that a new accord will be reached this year. A poll showed 77% want a negotiated solution, while only 19% support a military solution. The government is fighting to salvage the peace deal and extended meetings with opposition leaders.

The conflict has killed over 220,000 people and displaced millions. President Juan Manuel Santos won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to end the conflict. A new accord will be submitted to Congress for approval, rather than put to another referendum.

The agreement was rejected in a referendum last month but is expected to be approved by Congress. A bilateral ceasefire has been broken for the first time since its implementation, with two rebels killed in combat.

The accord includes provisions to disarm rebels, who have been extorting people and carrying weapons. Rebels were ordered to stop offensive military activities, including sabotage, as part of a two-month cease-fire announced earlier. The government and rebels are set to sign the final agreement on Thursday.

A majority of Colombians support peace talks with Marxist rebels, but doubt that a new accord will be reached this year. The conflict has killed over 220,000 people and displaced millions. President Juan Manuel Santos won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to end the conflict. A new accord will be submitted to Congress for approval, rather than put to another referendum.

called the secession, it held its own exhibitions and found a steady source of patronage in the city's wealthy bourgeois elite. in line with his outsider status, klimt worked a bit at being a character. he took to dressing in blue, muumuu-like floor-length smocks inside and outside the studio, and had himself photographed in them, looking soulful. i've always had trouble with klimt's iconic figurative paintings. their insistent visual flash looks as hard and sleek as the surface of a credit card; their sexiness seems lacquered over and their byzantine theatricality slightly silly and already old-fashioned. Additionally, a proposed strip mine in northern Alabama would have released toxic pollution directly into the Black Warrior River, which supplies drinking water to over 200,000 residents.

Coal mining companies are facing criticism for their practices, including allegations of hiring paramilitary gunmen and releasing toxic waste into waterways. RELIABLE NEWS SUMMARY
---------------------
Mountaintop mining has caused environmental damage, burying or choking 1,200 miles of Appalachian streams and damaging hundreds of square miles of forests. The practice is allowed despite violating regulations due to financial influence from the coal industry. A federal judge halted four mountaintop removal projects, citing failure to demonstrate irreversibility and inadequate environmental reviews.

In Hopewell, a measure on the local ballot would cut the open space fund in half, threatening forests, farms, water, and wildlife. The township government commissioned a fiscal impact study concluding that development would lead to higher property taxes.

Tap water contamination is a serious issue in some areas, with wells being contaminated due to pollutants seeping into the ground. State regulators released new rules governing groundwater pollution, adjusting limits for hundreds of chemicals and establishing new rules for developers planning to restore polluted areas.

In Lindytown, residents signed documents agreeing not to sue or comment on coal-mining operations, receiving $25,000 each in exchange. The mining operation is transforming the area, erasing woodsy stretches.

The Sierra Club has a history of conflict with its New York City group, which opposes construction projects and sees the organization as part of the "sellout" of the environmental movement. A lawsuit is ongoing over the city group's ouster.

The Onondaga Nation is pursuing a land claim against the state, seeking influence in policy discussions affecting their ancestral lands and protection for ancestors' gravesites and the environment. They do not seek compensation involving money

Earnings recovery is expected, with improving profits buoyed by rising employment and business spending. The Australian dollar and Brazilian real are showing signs of strength in 2016.

Tech shares stumbled after an early rally, with investors focusing on retail and consumer products sectors instead. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended trading up 47.74 points, or 0.5%, to close the day.

Investors are cautious about the coming year, with some executives expressing caution about growth. Market breadth was impressive during Monday's session, with 90% of NYSE volume associated with advancing issues.

Article 4 - the world is finite, with finite resources
to the editor: in “a terrible bust is born” (column, june 30), roger cohen chronicles many important problems with the united states and the global economy related to increasing commodity prices. but he doesn’t mention the underlying cause of our situation. metaphoric phrases, like “the world is no longer flat, it’s upside-down,” don’t provide an adequate explanation. the basic cause is the literal fact that the world is finite. there is only a finite amount of usable resources. i stress usable, because as we use up the most readily available of our resources, it requires more of our other resources just to find, extract, process and distribute what’s left. matter and energy cannot be destroyed, but the ability to extract useful work from them is destroyed by each of us in our everyday lives. we are fortunate to be alive on a world with such diversity of natural resources. let the recent increase of most commodity prices be a wake-up call that the world is finite. william culver washington, june 30, 2008  to the editor: “a terrible bust is born” is worth keeping and remembering. thanks to roger cohen for his perceptive and pertinent insight into the coming bear market. and thanks for the optimism at the end of his column. hugh gordon nelson, new zealand, july 2, 2008

Article 1 - squeezing the milky way into a photo
photo q. when i see a published photograph purporting to be of the entire milky way, i wonder, was it really possible for someone to take it? a. many of the photos illustrating the milky way are actually top or bottom views of other presumably similar galaxies. an earthbound observer cannot stand outside earth’s home galaxy and photograph its overall pinwheel structure, with its spiraling arms and central cluster of stars. earth is in a corner of what humans see as a diffuse nighttime haze of stars. one model often chosen as a stand-in is the galaxy messier 74, because many scientists assume its spiral looks the way the milky way would look if photographed from above or below its plane. another stand-in has been the neighboring andromeda galaxy, or messier 31. a satellite image of the milky way from within the galaxy shows some indications of its structure. a groundbreaking panoramic view was made in 1990 by the cosmic background explorer satellite, capturing near-infrared wavelengths of light in a time exposure. it shows the central bulge of stars as a bright spot placed at the middle of a thin line that represents the sparser collection reaching out in either direction. if this image were wrapped around the viewer, it would be very close to how an edge-on view of a spiral galaxy would appear.

Medicare and Medicaid can outmatch private plans on cost for certain services, but doctors tend to treat all patients similarly regardless of who is paying the bill. The new reimbursement formula has left millions of insured families more vulnerable to catastrophic medical bills.
